docs.title: Syntax
docs.text:
Pronouns: NLL

  • N: Generally a number, can be

    • 1 for 1st person,
    • 2 for 2nd person,
    • 3 for 3rd person, or
    • I for the impersonal pronoun.

  • L: A letter representing quantity, can be

    • S for singular,
    • P for plural.

  • L: A letter representing the type of pronoun, can be

    • S for subject,
    • O for object,
    • P for possessive,
    • Ref for reflexive,
    • D for demonstrative,
    • Int for interrogative,
    • Rel for relative, and
    • Ind for indicative.

Verbs: TTTNL

  • TTT: A trio of letter, indicating the time of the verb. Can be

    • INF for infinitive,
    • PAS for past tense, or
    • PRE for present tense.

  • N: A number, indicating the type of person (see the N in pronouns).

  • L: A letter, representing the quantity of the associated pronoun (See the second L in pronouns).

docs.title: Contexts of use and language choice
Constituent Order in Main Clauses
docs.text:
Frisian, as well as the other languages derived from avshenese, are of a mixed constituent order. Yet, they are all Subject-Object-Verb (SOV) languages.

  1. e te gume kukufe

    3SS - 3SP home - PST3S leave

    "He left his home"

docs.title: Verb Phrase
docs.text:
Adverbs only precede the verb. In the following example, we see xerevo already/previously precedes the verb fufuse was.

  1. dad e xa e thate xerevo fufuse fofovene

    (COORD) and - 3SS - (COMP) that [3SS - good - already PST3S is] - PST3S learn

    "And he learned that he was already good"

docs.title: Tanethism
docs.text:
Old Tanethism was characterized by its myriad of gods—one for each apomantic signature. This religion was widely practiced in the Seven Princedoms of the Sea and their various colonies up to the late Age of Spring. However, in the year 520 A.S., by decree of the god-suzerain Olag, a "new" Tanethism was established as the official religion of the princedoms. Today, this is the most practiced religion in the Fesh Peninsula.

The religion is based on a book published by Taneth in 311 A.S., in which the scholar and traveler wrote an exhaustive compilation of the more than a thousand deities praised in the region. In this taxonomy, they classified the similitudes and differences between most of these deities and proposed a reduced pantheon with a clear, tiered hierarchy between all of them.

While now considered a sacred scholar, Taneth's work was barely known during their life. They died in obscurity shortly after the publication, and no detail about them remains on paper apart from their name.

Most people have a favorite among the gods, one whose ideals and teachings they make their own. A few even dedicate themselves entirely to a single deity, serving as a priest, acolyte, or champion of that god. Some famous examples among these devotees are the Pagramic Nimrods, an organization of zealous hunters of Pagram who would pursue all who disturb the perceived balance. Another example is the followers of Havetish, who to this date seek to distribute wealth and food to the impoverished inhabitants in the inland regions.

A first glance into the Cosmos and its relation to the goddesses and gods of Tanethism, 796 A.S.. Each of the divinities that inhabits the heavens is presented around Darhoc and the Ring of Color that surrounds it. Recorded by the Fremite Monastery of Chist.

docs.title: The two primordial
docs.text:
The two primordial are the primal forces that created everything that exists. They are uppermost in the pantheon, and every creature in the continent acts in their reverence by the mere act of being alive.

  • Nix, the god of Unity, the cosmos, and inevitability.
  • Pheter, the god of Disparity, creation, war, and spring.

docs.title: Damic gods
docs.text:
The damic gods, or first gods in avshenese, are the firstborn of Pheter. They were the first disparity in the cosmos, light and dark, and inhabit the heavens in the shape of the sun and the third moon, the darksun.

  • Zash, the goddess of White, light, luck, beer, travel, immigrants, and gifts.
  • Fagal, the god of Black, darkness, mystery, beauty, oblivion, and property.

docs.title: Mevic gods
docs.text:
The mevic gods, or gods of bone, are the six aspects of Zash, and were created by the sun goddess and by Pheter in the Nascency of Color. Most of the gods inhabit their circular sectors in the Ring of Color, with the exception of Febrid and Fusine, who travel the cosmos alongside Zash and Fagal.

  • Matevos, the goddess of Green, lightness, joy, and the domestication of animals.
  • Febrid, or Nuagal, is the goddess of Blue, cold, intellect, time, and winter.
  • Fusine, or Kegal, is the goddess of Purple, chaos, the stars, retribution, and thunder.
  • Vahan is the god of Red, heaviness, mountains, and conflict.
  • Bagrat is the god of Orange, warmth, agriculture, benevolence, vigor, and summer.
  • Pagram is the god of Yellow, order, civilization, gold, and autumn.

docs.title: God-trees
docs.text:
The oric gods, or gods of flesh in avshenese, were the first trees in the world and are the creators of most living creatures in it. More commonly known as the god-trees, each was born of a seed during the First Communion, planted by their corresponding mevic god. Despite being divine beings, they are physical, and thus, mortal. Regretfully, most of them have died, either in the Schism or in the Penance.

  • Tek is an immense banyan, shaded by imposing green crowns. It was planted by Matevos, and is the parent of the elves.
  • Et was a blue birch with many-hued leaves. It was planted by Febrid, and is the creator of the humes.
  • Tol was another birch of a sickly white color. It sprouted from the burned stump of Et, and is the parent of the fey.
  • Uld was a kapok tree of striking height and a purple crown. It was the tree of Fusine, and created no kin but educated many.
  • Kan, a fire-starter tree unique in Yuadrem, was the tree of Vahan.
  • Om is a vigorous orange juniper with shy saffron crowns. It was the tree of Bagrat, and spawned and raised the imates.
  • Ur, a fir with countless golden crowns, was the tree of Pagram.

docs.title: Illuminants
docs.text:
The tovasic gods, or second gods in avshenese, are mortals who are given godhood by higher gods through a ritual of ascension. Better known as illuminants, they are usually protagonists of legends, becoming deities after death and watching over the world alongside the mevic gods from the heavens.

  • Avenush is the god of teaching and tactics. As a mortal, they were an elf who mediated the peace between Gannag and the Seven Princedoms, then proceeded to create the gannagian apomantic system. They were ascended by Febrid, and their depictions show a body covered entirely by a most complex network of apomantic signatures, a glyph carved into each centimeter of bark.

  • Eful and Geful are the goddesses of justice, the sky, knowledge, and love. As mortals, they were two fey scholars who provided the basis for modern math and astrology. They were both ascended together by Fusine, and upon achieving godhood jumped to the heavens to continue their studies, becoming the twin astral bodies known as Relas.

Etian signature of Relas.

  • Elña is the goddess of tradition and forests. She was the "immortal" queen of the kingdom of Gronselar in the far south of the world. She was ascended by Pagram, and often takes the shape of a white deer, watching of the descendants of the gronselarian irds, who she still takes under her care.

  • Havetish is the god of both leadership and tyranny. Their mortal name was Qina, and were the elf warlord who led an army of their kin against the Jenkash's irds in the Na'anian wars. They were ascended by the god of conflict Vahan, and are depicted with a bark and a spear carved from purpleheart wood.

  • Laver, sometimes known as Gathoz, is the god of secrecy and murder. While their name in life is unknown, they are the assassin who battled and killed the god-suzerain Olag using Tetrachromacy. Now, they are often attributed to murders where the perpetrator is never found. They were ascended by Fusine during the night of the murder, and are depicted as a kinless being, their face and body shifting under rags. Due to their great sin, they were not allowed into the Ring of Color, and thus now orbits the heavens as an astral body.

Etian signature of Laver.

  • Mziva is the god of self-sacrifice. As a mortal, she was an imate who led her people to salvation during the Ededian Massacre, at the cost of her own life. She was ascended by Tamaz, and is depicted with golden hair and clothes made of flowers.

  • Nikoleta, also known as Bades, is the goddess of rituals and sorcery. As a mortal, she was a gat sorceress from Fremit and a scholar of Nix. She created an incantation that temporarily stops the spread of nix, and cast it atop Mount Tashta to stop the tar from invading the Fesh Peninsula. The ritual killed her, but was ascended by Febrid upon death. Her incantation is repeated every year in various parts of the Punika Ridge to continue protecting the peninsula. She ascended to the heavens after death, and became the astral body Bades.

Etian signature of Bades.

  • Olag is the god of craftsmanship and conquest. They were the first of the illuminants, and the god-suzerain of the Seven Princedoms of the Sea. They were an Et-born who ascended by Vahan's will in 195 A.S., and died in 621 A.S..

  • Rerisi, sometimes known as Zuleija, is the god of discipline and protection. She was the only Et-born able to reproduce, and is the mother of all treb gats. She was a formidable fighter, and is the one who slayed the mighty beasts of the Sylvan Canyon, allowing for the establishment of the princedom of Viphoger. She was ascended by Vahan for her strength, and is depicted with weapons and armor made of heavy stone. She soared to the heavens after her death, and is now the farthest astral body from Darhoc.

Etian signature of Rerisi.

  • Sakris is the god of fun and wine. As a mortal, he was the most devoted slave to the prince-merchant Hak of Ushpavam. Ascended by Matevos, he is often depicted dutifully attending to guests at a party, even as a god.

  • Tamaz is the goddess of wealth and silver. As a mortal, she was an ird adventurer, known for financing the first colonial ships of Krudzal. She is now depicted in a shiny gray dress, holding an iron hammer and a woodworking saw, and was ascended by the god of civilization, Pagram.

  • Tinos, sometimes known as Genadi, is the goddess of bravery and compassion. As a mortal, she was an imate hero whose acts led to the death of King D'khan, ending the Ededian Massacre. She was ascended by Bagrat, and is depicted with toad-like features, carrying her characteristic swordflute. She rose to the heavens after death, and now wards her fellow imates as an astral body.

Etian signature of Tinos.
  • Vugar is the god of family and generosity. As a mortal, he was the protected prince of the kingdom of Vamerit and was renowned for establishing laws pertaining to family and hereditary rights to the Seven Princedoms. He was ascended by Bagrat, and is often depicted with a silver toga of simple style.

As far as is known, there exist only four illuminants alive in the Fesh Peninsula at the current date. Skepticism is encouraged, however, as mevic gods have performed many ascensions surreptitiously, with the echelon of the new god only divulged years later, sometimes posthumously.

  • Anush, also known as Doran, is the god of rot and fertility. They are an elf born outside the reach of Tek, and thus unable to commune with the god-tree. Rather than becoming feral, like their kin in Knagan, the illuminant didn't let their birth become a weakness, and now spreads tekust spores and assists in funerary rituals across the Fesh Peninsula. They were recently ascended by Bagrat, which has only emboldened their spirit and that of their followers.

  • Do Zazuzu is the god of mischief and pageants. He is an oras imate famous for his role in the independence of Viphoger and his graceful antics. He was ascended by the god of joy Matevos, and now runs a traveling company of troubadours and acrobats that performs all around the Fesh Peninsula.

  • Jirek is the god of might and salt. He is a treb that was ascended by Vahan after he bested and killed the god's previous champion, Rerisi. The illuminant is now one of the chiefs of Nalash, and lives in the Ruti mountains waiting for challengers to try and take his title.

  • Vakris is the god of madness and scavengers. He is a dral who was the leader of an infamous band of bandits in the Idul Ridge before being captured by Vawe, the Regent Prince of Ushpavam. He was exiled after having his group slaughtered and his body disfigured through torture, yet was later ascended in a perverse act of kindness by the goddess of retribution Fusine. He now roams the ridge readying his vengeance, while madly striking any who approach him.

docs.title: Fagal
docs.text:
Fagal is the god of Black, Darkness, Mystery, Beauty, Oblivion, and Property.

Nothing is her incarnation, and she is commonly associated to private property. They are the darksun, providing darkness to the night and saturation to color. While the god doesn't usually appear on the planet, they seldom take the form of a king vulture, momentarily blocking the light of the sun with their colossal body.

Fagal sometimes appears to mortals on dreams, acting as portent of great change in one's life. In these opportunities, they appear as a dark, indistinct figure, cloaked in a mantle of stars.

Glyphs associated with Fagal: the fundamental signature of darkness, and the etian glyph of Fagal.

docs.title: Zash
docs.text:
Zash is the goddess of White, Light, Luck, Beer, Travel, Immigrants, and Gifts.

Color is her incarnation, and she is often associated with acts of hospitality and of celebration. She is the sun, creator of Color, and mother to all mevic gods. When her astral body is covered by clouds, the goddess takes the form of a great white egret, blinding those who see her with her shining white feathers.

Zash sometimes visits households during the darkest nights, taking an indistinct hume figure in traveler clothes. Refusing extending hospitality to her is a grave mistake—often the last one—for she meets hostility in-kind.

Glyphs associated with Zash: the fundamental signature of light, and the etian glyph of the sun.

docs.title: Et
docs.text:
Et was the god-tree planted by Febrid, and its fruit are the humes.

The tree was a towering birch, its bark marked by deep blue indentations, and its leaves shining in different hues from ice to midnight colors. Its circumference was so great that, centuries after its death, the rim of its burnt stump became the outer wall of Naptane, the capital of the Seven Princedoms of the Sea. Some time after the citadel's foundation, a second birch sprouted from the burned stump—the god-tree Tol.

At the beginning of history, the trees Et and Om were locked in an eternal conflict known as the War of Autumn, which concluded in the burning of Om at the hand of Et's children, the humes. Pheter, enraged, struck Et down with lightning, burning it together with its sibling god-tree.

docs.title: Kan
docs.text:
Kan was the god-tree planted by Vahan, and did not produce any progeny.

It was a plant unique in the world: red branches extended upward atop hundreds of meters of a dark gray trunk, evoking the mountainous strength of the mevic god that planted it. The god-tree stood in the middle of Krejek, capturing thunder from the clouds and erupting into seasonal firestorms that defined the landscape of the rocky island.

docs.title: Om
docs.text:
Om, also known as Tosh-drieln in jantherlin and the twice-born tree, is the god-tree planted by the god Bagrat and the parent of the imates.

The tree is a vigorous orange juniper with a complex root system that forms the many islands of the Turtle Sea. While the tree burned down in the Schism, it begat a second trunk from its eastern side over the centuries.

After the War of Summer began and the of the city of Thean was re-founded, Om's branches have begun to flaunt shy saffron crowns. These provide shade and the hope of a new future to the imates of the city, now finally back in their ancestral home.

docs.title: Tek
docs.text:
Tek, or Tekatsae in knaenese, is the god-tree planted by Matevos, and its the creator of the elves.

The tree is an immense banyan that stands tall in the Drejek Plateau, shading most of the jungle there with an imposing array of innumerable green crowns. Its root system spreads through the entirety of the plateau, giving life to every tree, plant, and fungus in it.

During the Penance, Tek not only protected its jungle from nix, it used its immense root system to lift a significant portion of the terrain. Slow and deliberate, it dragged the plateau toward the Fesh Peninsula, creating the plateau that stands now between the Punika and the Puneui mountain ridges.

docs.title: Tol
docs.text:
Tol was the smallest of the god-trees, and it sprouted from the stump of Et two centuries after the Schism. The tree's fruit were the fey, an initially enigmatic kin that later integrated into gat culture.

While it was a birch like its parent, Tol did not seem to have a relation with Blue, and its had a pattern and coloration similar to a moth's wing, rather than the blue of Et's bark and crowns. It was also much smaller is size, its circumference a mere hundred meter, and its crowns were of a sickly white color.

docs.title: Uld
docs.text:
Uld was the god-tree planted by Fusine.

Uld was a purple kapok tree of breathtaking scale, whose purple crown shaded the entirety of the Everwoods, and turned its center into a swamp known as the Pale Blemish. While the god-tree didn't produce any progeny, it befriended a band of wandering fey, who established the city-state of Ignelli on the labyrinthian passageways created by Uld's trunk and roots.

Along with the fey of Ignelli, the kapok tree invented the uldian tree of languages, informing a deeply academic society. The goddess Fusine herself would come down every two months to Ignelli, visiting the fey and exchanging knowledge with them.

docs.title: Ur
docs.text:
Ur was the god-tree planted by Pagram, and did not produce any progeny.

It was a fir with a tall, single straight trunk. Its branches, which sprouted in whorls, were crowned by leaves that kept a golden color year-round, their light scattering in the misty fjords of Stinos. Every autumn it would shed its innumerable leaves, giving the land its unique gilded coloration, and was an essential part of its ecology.

docs.title: Olag, the god-suzerain
docs.text:
Olag is the god of Craftsmanship and Conquest. Perhaps the most important figure in history, the illuminant was the suzerain of the Seven Princedoms of the Sea, moving civilization out of the Age of Winter and into the Age of Spring.

Olag was a dark-skinned Et-born gat with snow-white hair. They were larger in stature and bulkier in frame than the average hume, resembling a treb gat. They had two large horn similar to those of a stag, which grew across the illuminant's centuries of life, reaching a stunning size by the end of their time.

In life, Olag was an Et-born that spawned after the Schism as one of the last of their kind. In their youth, they unified the humes scattered during the 40-year Famine and established the kingdom of Vamerit near the charred remains of Et, placing themself as its regent. Hunger and sickness were rampant during Vamerit's early years, but this period of history was quickly left behind under the gat's guidance.

After founding the city of Naptane in 96 A.S., the neighboring tribes took notice of Olag's reign. While some reacted with respect for Et and swore fealty to the Et-born, many feared the unification brought by them and attacked the young empire, sparking the 100-year War. Through both bargain and warfare, the gat united each kingdom, city-state, and tribe in the Horned Shores under their banner. By the end of the war, they established the Seven Princedoms of the Sea, keeping Naptane as its capital. Vahan himself attended the coronation ceremony, ascending them into the first illuminant and bestowing the title of god-suzerain, and thus commenced the Age of Spring.

During this age, Olag expanded continued to expand their reign further and further south, reaching the Chirping Wilds in its maximum extension. In this process, they fought many wars, established commerce thorough all of the continent, and established Tanethism as the only religion in the empire. A sculptor themself, the gat scattered statues of their visage across all of the empire, reminding the people of who their emperor was.

While the imperial goals of the god-suzerain were fruitful for the most part, they strained the core of the empire. The protected princes protested and some, upon having their demands ignored, rebelled. While most of these were kept under control, the princedom of Xarxage refused to be silenced. As the years passed, The illuminant became more and more desperate, and ultimately, in 620 A.S., called on the signature of the all-storm, once used by Pheter to strike down Et, to destroy the princedom's capital, Alagias.

This act caused Xarxage to descend into anarchy, and quelled the revolution in all princedoms. Olag's reign, once sustained through respect and strength, now existed only due to the fear of what the god-suzerain was capable of. Less than a year later, however, an unknown assassin somehow sneaked into the their bedroom, cutting this dreadful empire short with the pierce of a knife. This event is known as the Night of the Fourth Color, and marks the end of the Age of Spring. While the murderer was never caught, they themself became an illuminant, ascended by Fusine.

Olag's death, as deserved as it was, was still a shock to the world. It led to the collapse of the princedoms, as the old structures of power could not be sustained without their figurehead. The only thing that remains of the god-suzerain now are their derelict statues, crumbling and mossy.

docs.title: Bagrat
docs.text:
Bagrat is the god of Orange, Heat, Agriculture, Benevolence, Vigor, and Summer.

Earth is his incarnation, and he is associated with kindness, charity, and healthcare. He manifests to mortals frequently in the body of a campo troupial, blooming flowers and hasting the growth of crops. On occasion, he also takes the form of a horned hume with simple clothes, working the fields of a tired farmer with tools made of red gold.

The glyph of Bagrat, the fundamental signature of warmth.

docs.title: Febrid
docs.text:
Febrid is the goddess of Blue, Cold, Intellect, Time, and Winter.

Wood is her incarnation, and she is related to the stability of both individuals and communities. The goddess doesn't show herself often on Yuadrem, but from time to time does so when places of knowledge, such as libraries and monasteries, are built. In these occasions, she takes the shape of a subtle azure jay, and can be recognized for the trail of dew in her path.

Febrid can be seen in the night sky in as Nuagal, Darhoc's second moon. In this form, she is an astral body composed only of one deep ocean, which sometimes appears to scholars in dreams, usually before a great revelation.

Two glyphs associated with Febrid: the fundamental signature of cold and the etian glyph of nuagal.

docs.title: Fusine
docs.text:
Fusine is the goddess of Purple, Chaos, the Stars, Retribution, and Thunder.

Metal is her incarnation, and she is associated with the resolution of conflicts, especially when done through combat. Like her sister Febrid, Fusine doesn't often appear on the land; she's only been seen ephemerally as a swallow-tailed hummingbird, her flight followed by the passage of a terrible storm.

The goddess doesn't live in the Ring of Color, but rather flies in the night sky as the moon Kegal. Fusine was tasked with the destruction of Et by Pheter in the Schism, and her surface is marked with the etian signature of the All-Storm.

In addition to her manifestation as a bird, she sometimes also appears to mortals on dreams, often before terrible natural disasters. In these occasions, she takes the form of a black-bellied slider turtle, her shell shining with a million stars.

Three glyphs associated with Fusine: the fundamental signature of chaos, the etian glyph of kegal, and the signature of the All-Storm

docs.title: Matevos
docs.text:
Matevos is the goddess of Green, Lightness, Joy, and the Domestication of animals.

Water is her incarnation, and she is often associated to the essential needs of a person. The goddess often manifests to mortals in the shape of a grey-breasted parakeet, screaming in accusation of those who would deny others their means to survive. She sometimes takes the form of a hume, appearing as a two-horned gat with light clothes, wielding a green bident with nimble expertise.

The glyph of Matevos, the fundamental signature of lightness.

docs.title: Pagram
docs.text:
Pagram is the god of Yellow, Order, Civilization, Gold, and Autumn.

Stone is his incarnation, and is celebrated in the formation of cities and their associated rituals. Pagram manifests as a golden parakeet, his fluttering following the flowers that decorate a city. He sometimes appears to scholars as a horned hume philosopher, wearing white clothing, pompously adorned in gold.

The glyph of Pagram, the fundamental signature of order.

docs.title: Vahan
docs.text:
Vahan is the god of Red, Heaviness, Mountains, and Conflict.

Fire is his incarnation, and he is associated with the self-sufficiency of both people and communities. The mevic god appears often on Yuadrem as a scarlet ibis, scorching the earth wherever he steps, following the wake of wars and natural disasters. Vahan sometimes takes the form of a hume, a red-haired soldier wearing a one-horned helm, wielding a large flanged mace with a firm grip.

The glyph of Vahan, the fundamental signature of heaviness.

docs.title: Nix
docs.text:
Nix is the god of Unity, the Cosmos, and Inevitability.

Their body is the cosmos itself: everything that exists is borrowed, and must eventually be returned to them. They have never manifested themself to a creature in the planet, but are are generally portrayed as a bare-faced curassow, its feathers iridescent like oil on water.

On the world, Nix manifests in the form of a black, iridescent sap, which is commonly named nix. This sap is the mix of all things, and is produced whenever disparity is enforced upon reality, such as when an incantation is cast, a life is born, or an idea is thought.

A glyph often associated with Nix, the etian signature of void.

docs.title: Pheter
docs.text:
Pheter is the god of Disparity, Creation, War, and Spring.

They were born from Nix in the Nascency of Disparity, and their arrival led to the creation of everything. Pheter is the progenitor of the damic and mevic gods, and all creation leads back to the divinity. They've revealed themself to mortals in many occasions, most commonly in the form of a pair of maguari storks, an equal balance of the six colors dancing through their bodies.

In Darhoc, they manifest as a transparent, inodorous matter that permeates the entirety of the planet, simply named pheter. Every time disparity is created, it is conducted through this substance, consuming some of it. This wanton consumption is what led to the Age of Sap, and what will end up allowing nix to consume all of life.

Unlike the other gods, no glyph is associated to Pheter, as they are the one that gives meaning to symbols in the first place.
